section.title: Introduction
section.para: We have been working on this project for over a year now, sometimes more focused and sometimes less. You can say that we have achieved a lot, if you take into account that we have not used any engines, frameworks and libraries besides the core Java libraries. Anyways, to get the whole project go seriously, to realize an innovative, exiting, enjoyable, attracting game experience, we would need to work on it full time. As illonis and Ren are going to graduate with bachelor's in September 2014, it is a good occasion to start working fulltime in fall 2014.

section.title: How are we going to finance working full time??
section.para: Good question! As we should not risk starving or becoming homeless due to a lack of money in our wallet, we would need to get some money from somewhere. The idea is to raise money on a crowdfunding platform like kickstarter or indiegogo. I think about 30.000 Euro would be sufficient to keep two developers alive and finance additional hard- and software we would need to purchase. Any extra money can of course be invested to involve externals or hire further developers/specialists to speed up and improve the development. Unfortunately, I have no idea of the likelihood of raising so much money. But I think it's worth the try.

section.title: Why would someone invest in Eduras??
section.para:
Good question! I believe there are some critical factors we have to focus on to maximize money we can raise from other people.
Quality: Very important is to be able to present a prototype of Eduras that shows where the journey is going, what is special about Eduras and why it's worth to wait for and invest in it.
Quantity: No matter how good an Eduras prototype is: If nobody knows about it, nobody can spend money on it. We have to make sure that as many people as possible become aware that Eduras is out there and ready to go.
Vision: We need a precise idea of what we want to make in the future and present it in an exciting way.

section.title: General approach to implementing tasks
section.para: No matter what you do, you should always have on mind that we're implementing a prototype. If Eduras should really become a serious project next fall, we will have to rethink everything anyways because I believe that due to our small experience in game development many things will have to be started over. That means, for now, we should not focus on perfect software architecture but rather use dirty hacks if it's needed and speeds things up in the scope of our limited time window. For example, don't write documentation unless it's really critical in order to work with it. Consider that most likely no further developers will join our team until next year.

section.title: Features to implement for prototype
section.para: The timeline seen above indicates what features to implement. Let me explain them more precisely here.

The ingame chat, launcher and bug tracker are already there, but not all of them are working properly. The launcher / installer needs to be fixed with windows, the ingame chat has to be integrated and fixed too. The bug tracker should be made accessible on the Eduras website protected by an authentication mechanism (which is basically there already, too). The UDP hole punching is implemented, but doesn't work with some routers, we need to figure that out. We should get these issues solved before we start something new, because they are critical to potential beta testers.

Rotation means the main figure's front should look towards the direction of the mouse pointer. Hitboxes should rotate simultaneously. Furthermore, missiles should be released at the tip of the figure's front (maybe a designated vertex) instead of arbitrarily "somewhere in front" of the figure.
The rocket launcher's missiles are relativly slow. When they collide, they explode and make great damage not only to the hit target but also to objects in a certain area of effect.
Mines are like rocket launcher missiles, but they dont move.
An assault rifle is a weapon with very low damage, but infinitly high speed and low cooldown.
Flexible settings means what is discussed in the 'Settings' document.
Ammunition is of course what you think it is. When you shoot, your ammo decreases, when you collect a weapon, the ammo for that weapon increases by some number.

It might be necessary to make objects better distinguishable from each other, for example weapons and missiles. We can do that in a very simple way by designing different shapes for weapons and assign them different colors. Don't spend to much time on real animations as we don't have it and it's not that critical to the game experience.
The conquer-mode will basically be what is described in the 'gameplay' document.

Interactive mode spots are small designated areas where a player can switch from ego-mode to interactive-mode. It is usually in or close to a neutral base (or even the same). A neutral base is a designated area. If a player of your team stays in there for a certain amount of time without any player from another team coming in this area during that time, your team takes over control of that base.

Each team has a shared 'resource' pool. There is only one resource and everything you do in interactive-mode you have to pay for with that resource. The resource pool increases over time. The more bases you control, the faster it grows. Additionally, for every player of the opponent's team that you kill, you gain some extra amount of resources.

As players in interactive mode can scroll through the map freely and for this gamemode it is essential that you don't know what your opponent is doing, we need to implement some kind of vision. As a first approach, we can implement that every unit your team controls and every main figure provides vision in a circle around the unit as you know it from common RTS games.

When a player is in interactive mode, he should have an RTS-like interface. That interface should show the current amount of resources, a mini-map to navigate through the map faster and a list of all the actions the player can perform in interactive mode. So there should be a tab for spells, unit production and tech upgrades each. There should be a shortcut for each action the player can perform. The unit factory is a physical object on the map where newly built units pop out. Tech and spell factory are meta terms for however you want to implement it. Also, the user should be able to assign hotkeys to groups of units or single objects dynamically.

When using the heal spell, the user has to click an area in the map and all units in your team which are in that area are healed by some amount. Through tech upgrades you can increase the radius and effectivness of the heal spell. The vision spell provides vision for a few seconds in the area the user clicks on on the map. Through tech upgrades you can increase the duration and range of the vision spell. Observer units are small, very fast and cost extensive units that only provide vision but cannot do anything else. Bomb units are like rocket missiles, but you can control where they go. Star units are weak units, that can shoot. They don't shoot automatically, so the user has to trigger that manually. The units will shoot towards the point the user clicks on.

In the prototype's spectator mode the spectator should be able to scroll freely as well as to follow a particular user. Furthermore the spectator shall be shown all the statistics that are available. To pull away all the traffic from the game server and thus avoid lags for the player, we will implement a spectator-bot-client, that connects to a game server as a spectator and forwards all the information to real spectators which connect to the spectator bot instead of to the game server.

section.title: Test events and test phase
section.para: The beta test phase will start in March after we will have fixed most things that prevent a fluid and easy game experience and all the enviroment for testers is up and running. At that point of time, the performance should have been made good enough to enjoy the game without too much frustration due to lags or errors. We will run game servers 24/7 then so testers can play whenever they want. Furthermore, we will have designated test events where we invite 10 - 15 people to play at the same time to watch the performance when there is big traffic. We can invite our friends as beta testers , I'm sure we will find enough among them, who like to play video games ;). They can give feedback directly to us or via the provided forum and bug trackers. We will encourage them to be as honest as possible and not care about our feelings. In June we will have a designated test phase that lasts about two months. By that date, all implementation should be finished. From then on, we will focus on fixing bugs and change/modify/add/remove whatever results from the feedback we get from our testers. That might involve balancing and even adding more weapons, units and spells if it turns out that the current functionality is not convenient enough. To address all the possible issues that might arise the test phase is as long as it is. After the test phase the prototype should be more or less final. That doesn't mean that we don't fix bugs if we still find some.

section.title: Advertising Eduras
section.para: I believe it is really important to advertise your crowdfunding project very much in order for the people to spend money on it. I believe that we have to make some kind of a show out of the whole process. I have seen many projects whose basic idea was great but it was presented poorly. These project did not reach their goal. And I have seen projects that were rather boring but advertised like hell. These projects did not only reach their goal but also exceeded it by far.

While we will not have spent much money on the Eduras project to this point of time, I think it will be necessary to invest some money now. The idea is to have an Eduras tournament with an attractive amount of prize money. The tournament would take place just a few days after the release of the prototype. Due to the fact that nobody can practise much because of the little time anyone can win and this will attract many people to participate in the tournament. Furthermore, people will experience the game and its idea under competitive conditions. To grab as much attention as possible, we can stream the whole tournament on a weekend and make a show out of it. On the stream we can advertise Eduras and the crowdfunding project very efficently as people directly see and hear what the project is about.

Of course, before that we have to ensure that people are aware of the event. I think mass spams on social network and gaming websites will do the trick to point people to what we have to offer. The gaming community is very good at informing themselves and others, I believe.

More important will be what we have to offer besides the tournament. We not only have to provide a lot of information but also present them in a rousing way. Maybe we should look for some professional help if this is not too expensive. A whole month from 01.08 to 01.09 is scheduled time to figure that out.

section.title: Risks
section.para: illonis and Ren are graduating in the end of September 2014. It's realistic, that they will not focus on their bachelor's thesis as much as they could and thus might get a worse grade than they could achieve under normal circumstances. But it's also true that if they continue studying for master's degree anyways, no one will give a shit on what grade they had in their bachelors degree. Another risk is that they might lose money. If the goal given in the crowdfunding campaign is not reached, they won't get anything in return to the effort made before. I think the total expenses will be about 2500 Euro, depending on how much we spend on prize money. We will need to rent several more servers to run Eduras on for a month which are about 80 Euro each. Additionally, we might need to hire some professionals to some marketing or legal (?) stuff for maybe about 500-1000 Euro. I don't know how to make a more precise estimate.

section.title: Chances
section.para: illonis and Ren are graduating in the end of September 2014. It is THE best occasion to start something own. If they don't reach the goal, they can simply keep on studying as nothing has happened but have made another experience. If they reach the goal but however things get screwed up later, they will have made A LOT of new experiences and can simply continue studying afterwards. But if things actually work out we will not only have got EVEN MORE EXPERIENCE but also made a dream come true.

section.title: Summary
section.para: Besides some money we have nothing at all to lose.
